awd_titl_txt: INFEWS/T3: Coupling infrastructure improvements to food-energy-water system dynamics in small cold region communities: MicroFEWs
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project seeks to develop a process by which researchers and community members together characterize how renewable energy infrastructure might impact the Food-Energy-Water (FEW) nexus in isolated Arctic and Subarctic communities. The research is critical because Arctic and Subarctic communities in the US and beyond represent some of the world's least secure communities with respect to provision of food, energy, and water. A systems approach acknowledging the linkages between food, energy, and water security holds great promise for developing integrated solutions. Such communities are ideally suited as model systems for the FEW nexus as they are geographically isolated, often inaccessible by roads, highly dependent on imported FEW resources, and often dependent upon isolated microgrids for distribution of local power. Due to this isolation, links between FEW infrastructure components are more readily observed compared to those in larger, interconnected communities elsewhere, and perturbations to the system can be more readily predicted. While introducing renewable energy infrastructure to the local microgrid in such communities could potentially enhance energy security by reducing their dependence upon imported fossil fuels, this introduction could also adversely impact the stability of the microgrids themselves or variably impact the linked infrastructure and processes contributing to food and water security. In pursuing a comprehensive approach that directly engages community stakeholders as well as researchers, the work seeks to ensure that any impacts to food, energy, and water security imposed by introducing renewable energy generation infrastructure to Arctic and Subarctic communities are universally positive. 

This research project represents a series of tasks addressing two key research questions: 1) What are the direct and indirect linkages between renewable energy generation and local drivers of FEW security in Arctic and Subarctic communities? 2) To what extent can combinations of renewable energy generation and FEW-related infrastructure energy loads be optimized to enhance FEW security in Arctic and Subarctic communities? The project derives expertise from two US universities, one Canadian university, three rural Alaska communities, and a host of associated stakeholders across Alaska. Key tasks include 1) engaging communities and developing place-based FEW metrics; 2) measuring existing FEW flows and feedbacks within the communities; 3) evaluating new technologies capable of impacting the local FEW nexus; 4) developing energy distribution models to optimize on-grid infrastructure components; 5) evaluating those optimization scenarios in the broader framework of the local FEW nexus using the previously-defined metrics; and 6) communicating results in diverse formats tailored for local residents and the broader scientific community. While analytical tools for optimizing grid configurations in the presence of renewable sources are available, they are designed for time-averaged performance and do not account for short-term fluctuations in sources or demands. This project capitalizes on those short-term fluctuations so that excess energy, when available, will be diverted to dispatchable loads serving FEW-enhancing objectives. Novel energy distribution models and controls are being developed to operate on timescales necessary to optimize the performance of intermittent renewable sources powering FEW-enhancing dispatchable loads. In addition to the advances offered in renewable energy management and control, the broader process represents an innovative approach to evaluating the FEW nexus. By framing the local FEW nexus around the infrastructure linked by the grid system, this work captures a thin cross section of the nexus that can be readily measured and manipulated. In linking off-grid FEW processes to the more concrete on-grid processes, MicroFEWS offers a novel and potentially scalable approach to understanding FEW dynamics in the Arctic, Subarctic, and beyond.

por.por_cntn:
The Food-Energy-Water Nexus concept has been used for studying the connections and tradeoffs among these three interacting systems. The MicroFEWs project sought to apply a FEW framework to Alaskan rural communities, which are different in several ways. First, the communities are electrically islanded microgrids, not connected to a state or national grid. Second, Alaskan communities do not in general lack access to fresh water; however, treatment and delivery, and especially sewage treatment, is rudimentary. Third, food in Alaska is often obtained locally from wild sources, such as game and berries. However, supplies of conventional grocery store products such as flour, milk, etc, are insecure, since these foodstuffs are imported via long distribution chains. MicroFEWs examined the connections and tradeoffs among the Food, Energy, and Water systems in these unique communities. 

The case study communities of Tanana, Kongiginak, Cordova, and Igiugig span different regions in Alaska with different climate and social conditions. We also partnered with researchers at Kluane Lake Research Station, which is an islanded microgrid in the Yukon Territory. MicroFEWs sought to develop, in close coordination with participating communities, the knowledge necessary to understand the impacts of introducing new renewable energy sources to small community microgrids. More specifically, the team sought to understand the impacts of new energy sources upon broader elements of the food-energy-water nexus within the communities.  

The project objectives are: 1) Framework Development, 2) Community Data Collection, 3) Modular Systems Case Studies, 4) Energy Distribution Models, 5) MicroFEWs Synthesis, and 6) Outreach and Capacity Development. All objectives were fulfilled.

Data collection included survey data on FEW usage and perceptions of security, technical data on power production and usage, and data on water plant operation and its power consumption.  The data enabled us to establish a FEW framework in rural Alaskan communities.  A permanent GitHub repository was created for all project products and data.

We tested several modular systems for producing food locally and treating sewage at the household level instead of pumping it to a centralized plant, which would require a constant input of heat to keep from freezing. “Lifewater” is a household wastewater treatment system designed for cold regions that can treat domestic wastewater and discharge clean water. We also tested a household water reuse system and a community greenhouse, both also designed for cold regions. We tested the ability of these systems to operate on renewable power and used the data to inform energy distribution models to optimize the match with renewable power generation. The team also designed and built a solar-powered, off-grid, actively cooled root-cellar to aid in food preservation in rural areas. We instrumented and implemented a public “data dashboard” for the KLRS energy and modular applications systems so that energy generation and usage at the station can be continually accessed.  

Detailed energy distribution models (EDMs) were developed and used to simulate microscale FEW system interactions in the four stakeholder communities. Community energy resource data were used in the EDMs with different FEW infrastructure loads to validate the models and determine the impact of additional or new renewable energy integration on the FEW system. 

The team developed a Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) using the edX platform on “Renewable Energy for Arctic Food and Water Security.” The research tools and processes developed and refined via MicroFEWs were used in the course to promote a holistic understanding of the FEW nexus at a level accessible to community members, decision makers, students, and interested citizens. 

We have worked closely with community members to understand and qualify/quantify the relationships among food, energy, and water in remote Alaska communities, resulting in a dissemination of knowledge and awareness of the importance of such relationships.  We produced and published videos including community members discussing aspects of the FEW Nexus relevant to the individual communities.  These activities have impacted the FEW-related knowledge base in the communities.  

We concluded that the Nexus idea does not really match the main factors shaping FEW security in rural Alaska, because other factors such as transportation, governance, and policy play a larger role than do the interactions within food, energy, and water systems. We also extended this idea to establish a framework for identifying the limiting factors, underlying causes, and possible solutions in Food-Energy-Water security.  The intent is to go beyond identifying deficiencies or shortcomings by pointing to proximate and ultimate causes of those deficiencies. The findings can be applied to other cold-climate communities as well as other rural regions that are not connected to their state grids.

Despite its limitations, nexus-style thinking is essential to identify trade-offs and synergies among the various systems and factors that determine FEW security. Our highly interdisciplinary team continues to work on different nexus intersections to gain better understanding of FEW interactions in remote Arctic communities.
